text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits IRM 1.14.8, Identifying Space Efficient Buildings.

On October 1, 2014 Real Estate and Facilities Management (REFM) merged with Physical Security and Emergency Preparedness (PSEP) to create Facilities Management and Security Services (FMSS). This IRM was updated to reﬂect current organizational titles.
As of January

, the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) instituted a requirement that the IRM addresses relevant internal controls. This will inform employees about the importance of and for internal controls by describing the program objectives and officials charged with program management and oversight. Internal controls are the program’s policies and procedures which ensure:

As of January 1, 2017, the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) instituted a requirement that the IRM addresses relevant internal controls. This will inform employees about the importance of and context for internal controls by describing the program objectives and officials charged with program management and oversight. Internal controls are the program’s policies and procedures which ensure:

a. Mission and program objectives are clearly delineated and key terms deﬁned. b. Program goals are established and performance is measured to assess the efficient and effective mission and objective accomplishment. c. Program and resources are protected against waste, fraud, abuse, mismanagement and misappropriation. d. Program operations are in conformance with applicable laws and regulations. e. Financial reporting is complete, current and accurate. f. Reliable information is obtained and used for decision making and quality assurance. Changed IRM
from “RLP Evaluations” to “Market Surveys and RLP Evaluations”. Removed IRM
, RLP Language.
This IRM supersedes IRM 1.14.8, published July 8, 2013.
Facilities Management and Security Services
Director Facilities Management and Security Services Agency
Wide Shared Services
Table of Contents
Efficient Buildings
) This IRM section applies to the evaluation of all future leased office space quisitions, whether through the General Services Administration (GSA) or through the IRS Delegated Leasing Program. (
) Purpose: This IRM section provides FMSS Territory Managers (TM) and staff with guidance to evaluate proposed leased properties for space (
) Audience: FMSS. (
) Policy Owner: Director, FMSS. (
) Program Owner: FMSS Associate Director, Real Property Management (RPM). (
) Primary Stakeholders: FMSS Employees. (

) This IRM contains guidelines for identifying building conditions that affect space efficiency. Building space efficiency is essential to the goal of the most efficient utilization of space by IRS personnel. (
) Executive Order
, Federal Real Property Asset Management,

, requires agencies to designate a Senior Real Property Officer who be responsible for implementing and developing a continuous and sive Asset Management Plan process for the agency. This process includes identifying and categorizing all real property owned, leased or otherwise managed by the agency; prioritizing actions to be taken to improve the tional and ﬁnancial management of the agency’s real property inventory, using public and commercial benchmarks and best practices to periodically evaluate all assets, among other executive-orders/
html (
) Treasury Directive
, Acquisition, Utilization, and Disposal of Treasury Real Property Assets, September

, contains provisions for the Treasury Department’s acquisition, management, and disposal of real assets by utilizing prudent asset management practices that optimize of space.https://www.treasury.gov/about/role-of-treasury/orders-directives/ Pages/td
aspx (

) FMSS Territory Managers must ensure that their Project Managers work GSA or the Real Property Leasing Officer (RPLO) to identify options that provide the best value to IRS in terms of cost and space efficiency. (
) FMSS Territory staff will identify for GSA, or the RPLO, space efficiency features important for the speciﬁc lease procurement requirement. (
) FMSS Territory Managers must ensure that the requirements for new or tinuing leases are developed far enough in advance to allow properties to evaluated for space efficiency. (
) FMSS Project Managers will include the evaluation for space efficiency in project ﬁles.
Space Efficient Buildings 1.14.8
Purpose: This IRM section provides FMSS Territory Managers (TM) and their staff with guidance to evaluate proposed leased properties for space efficiency.
FMSS Territory staff will identify for GSA, or the RPLO, space efficiency features important for the speciﬁc lease procurement requirement.

(1) The following acronyms are used throughout this document: Acronym Deﬁnition ANSI American National Standards Institute BOMA Building Owners and Managers Association BU Business Unit FMSS Facilities Management and Security Services GSA General Services Administration PSEP Physical Security and Emergency Preparedness REFM Real Estate and Facilities Man- agement RLP Request for Lease Proposal RLPO Real Property Leasing Officer R/U Rentable/Usable SFO Solicitation for Offers TM Territory Managers
The following acronyms are used throughout this document:

) One of the primary goals of the federal government is to manage resources the most efficient and economic manner practicable. FMSS is required to manage its stewardship funds, which comprise the majority of the FMSS budget, as effectively as possible. Since the stewardship budget consists mostly of rent, one of the ways FMSS can best administer its rent costs is through effectively managing and utilizing space. This can be accomplished leasing office space that is conﬁgured in such a way as to maximize the effi- ciency of ﬂoor plan and furniture layouts. (
) GSA is the primary service provider for IRS and in conjunction with the Treasury Department must follow all GSA and other federal provisions for effective asset management. (
) The Treasury Department granted delegated leasing authority to IRS in February
and through this program IRS is committed to practices for creating best value in leasing space by ensuring optimal space utilization. (
) The Treasury Department requires its agencies to develop and maintain prudent asset management practices that optimize utilization of space. (

) When acquiring new space, the most obvious means of reducing real estate costs are to lease only the minimally required area necessary for IRS to ac- complish its mission at the lowest possible rental rate.

One of the primary goals of the federal government is to manage resources the most efficient and economic manner practicable. FMSS is required to manage its stewardship funds, which comprise the majority of the FMSS budget, as effectively as possible. Since the stewardship budget consists mostly of rent, one of the ways FMSS can best administer its rent costs is through effectively managing and utilizing space. (09-27-2017) Effectively Managing and Utilizing Space
The Treasury Department requires its agencies to develop and maintain prudent asset management practices that optimize utilization of space.
Efficient Buildings

) Rental costs can be further minimized by selecting the most space efficient building possible. Many factors affect the efficiency of a ﬂoor plate such that two buildings with the same amount of usable office area may yield signiﬁ- cantly different levels of efficiency. Note: For example, a building with a
foot by
foot column spacing would much more efficient than one with a
foot by
foot column spacing. It not only the actual area taken up by these extra columns, but the of clear open space required for optimal space planning. (
) GSA and delegated IRS lease documents utilize the American National Standards Institute/Building Owners and Managers Association international standard (Z-
) deﬁnition for office area, known as BOMA Office Area” and previously usable square feet. (

) Other factors such as the age of the building inventory, the requirements of Business Unit (BU) or the number of leasing opportunities in any market inﬂuence which “space efficient” features can be best utilized. (

) An FMSS Territory has the obligation to evaluate potential lease sites conditions unique to the territory. a. The Territory should avoid sites where the building core location or elements of the ﬂoor plan preclude IRS from releasing marketable of space to GSA. Additionally, space should be conﬁgured, if possible, allow for future release of space with minimal alterations. b. Whenever possible, space on a single, larger and more efficient ﬂoor is preferable than space on multiple smaller ﬂoors. (
) The following are building factors or conditions that should be taken into account when evaluating a proposed office for space efficiency. (
) Floor Plates a. Full ﬂoors measuring
ANSI/BOMA office area (usable) square feet with a single core are most efficient. b. Full ﬂoors measuring

ANSI/BOMA office area (usable) square feet are typically inefficient. c. Rectangular ﬂoor plates with a single center core are most efficient. d. Buildings with curved exteriors are not efficient, especially for layouts. (

) Building Cores a. Split cores (e.g. stairwells are separated from the main core) may space layouts and will result in more circulation space. b. A core not centered on a ﬂoor may make it difficult to release space to GSA. (

) Walls & Columns a. Permanent walls constructed within the interior of a ﬂoor may affect optimal open space and office layouts and result in more circulation b. Extremely long, narrow runs of space can affect optimal open space office layouts. Internal Revenue Manual
Space Efficient Buildings 1.14.8

For example, a building with a 20 foot by 30 foot column spacing would be much more efficient than one with a 20 foot by 15 foot column spacing. It is not only the actual area taken up by these extra columns, but the of clear open space required for optimal space planning.
The following are building factors or conditions that should be taken into account when evaluating a proposed office for space efficiency.
(07-08-2013) Building Conditions that Affect Space Efficiency
a. Full ﬂoors measuring
ANSI/BOMA office area (usable) square feet with a single core are most efficient. b. Full ﬂoors measuring

ANSI/BOMA office area (usable) square feet are typically inefficient. c. Rectangular ﬂoor plates with a single center core are most efficient. d. Buildings with curved exteriors are not efficient, especially for layouts.

a. Split cores (e.g. stairwells are separated from the main core) may affect space layouts and will result in more circulation space. b. A core not centered on a ﬂoor may make it difficult to release marketable space to GSA.
Facilities c. The depth of perimeter columns can affect optimal open space and layouts since deeper columns can create unusable pockets of space between the columns. d. Column dimensions greater than

feet on center of the column will affect optimal space layout. Newer steel or concrete construction may have clear spans with few to no intervening columns. (

) Ceilings a. A standard GSA Request for Lease Proposal (RLP), previously known Solicitation for Offers (SFO), prescribes height minimums, but low conditions will restrict use of space. b. Sloped ceilings will restrict use of the space. (

) Windows a. ANSI/BOMA office area (usable) square feet measured from the inside the dominant feature of the exterior wall, which in most cases is the window glass. When window systems are situated in “deep pockets” of drywall, the result is less usable space. (

) Mechanical and Electrical System Conditions a. Walker duct ﬂoor systems for electric and telecommunications will limit open space and office planning. b. Induction units and baseboard heaters along the perimeter of the will affect optimal furniture layout. c. The main air return duct for a ﬂoor usually creates a noisy condition as enters the mechanical room. The RLP includes noise tolerances, but speciﬁc location may still restrict use of the ﬂoor space nearby. (

) Suite Conﬁguration and Contiguous Space a. Irregular suite conﬁgurations will impact open space and office layouts. b. Locating a requirement in the fewest number of suites within a building the most efficient and ﬂexible work arrangement. (

) The following building common area features will not make the tenant premises more or less efficient. However, the existence of these features in building may increase the Rentable/Usable (R/U) factor and may result in higher rental costs: a. The size of the main building lobby. b. The ﬂoor space pertinent to an atrium or light well. c. Common service areas such as building conference facilities, ﬁtness centers and vending areas. d. Buildings with an R/U factor greater than

Space Efficient Buildings 1.14.8
) The market survey of potential space is integral to ensure that not only will IRS mission needs be met, but that the government receives maximum and and utilization of the space to be procured. (

) Territory staff participating in market surveys must ensure that any potential spaces offered to the government meet the speciﬁcations of this IRM as it pertains to space efficiency and potential for efficient layout. (

) The standard RLP paragraphs pertaining to a potential building’s ability to deliver effective space utilization and mandatory requirements for location building quality, and other amenities, are: a. “Potential for Efficient Layout (August
)” b. “Neighborhood, Parking, Location Amenities and Public Transportation Inside City Center or Outside City Center (September
) If during a market survey, it is found that a potential building clearly does meet the criteria of IRM

), and is therefore unacceptable due to ciency or quality concerns, then Territory staff must not concur on the survey that the building will be solicited. Territory staff should document GSA was notiﬁed in writing that the unacceptable building should not be solicited. (

) Once the market survey of potential locations is complete and initial offers evaluated, territory staff must determine whether IRS space requirements be met within the square footage offered. If, due to inefficiencies that evident during the market survey; and it is clear requirements cannot be then the offer is unacceptable. If applicable, Territory staff should document that GSA was notiﬁed in writing that the building is unacceptable. (
) Once the market survey of potential locations is complete and initial offers evaluated, if it is not clear as to whether IRS requirements can be dated, territory staff, as permitted by IRM

) a), should make a request to have the Offeror provide a test-ﬁt layout at the Offeror’s Territory staff must evaluate the test-ﬁt layout and make a determination as whether the space offered is acceptable based on the efficiency of the ﬂoor plans. If a determination is made that the test-ﬁt is unacceptable, territory should document that GSA was notiﬁed in writing that the building is able.

Once the market survey of potential locations is complete and initial offers are evaluated, territory staff must determine whether IRS space requirements can be met within the square footage offered. If, due to inefficiencies that weren’t evident during the market survey; and it is clear requirements cannot be met, then the offer is unacceptable. If applicable, Territory staff should document that GSA was notiﬁed in writing that the building is unacceptable.
